greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Multiplicities of prime factors of A243103(n).
comment: Irregular triangle T(n,m) of multiplicities of the product of the numbers 1 <= k <= n | n^e with e >= 0.
Count of instances of primes p|n among the prime factors of all numbers 1 <= k <= n.
A243103(n) = Product of row n of A162306; prime divisors of A243103(n) = prime divisors of n = A027748(n).
a(1) = 0; a(p) = 1 for prime p. For prime powers p^e with e>=0, a(p^e) = A000217(e).
link: Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..11739 (rows 1 <= n <= 5000)
example: Row 12 = 9,5 because the numbers 1 <= k <= 12 | 12^e with e>=0, {1,2,3,4,6,8,9,12} and these have the prime decompositions:
Adding the multiplicities of the factors of 12 for each of these gives us 9,5.
Relationship of first 12 rows of a(n) with A027748(n) and A243103(n):
T(n,m) for n = primorial p_x# = A002110(x), with horizontal axis the multiplicity pertaining to prime(m):
mathematica: Table[With[{m = Floor@ Log2@ n}, Values@ Merge[Association /@ Map[#1 -> #2 & @@ # &, FactorInteger@ Rest@ Select[Range@ n, PowerMod[n, m, #] == 0 &], {2}], Total]] /. {} -> {0}, {n, 50}] // Flatten (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 17 2017, Version 10 *)
xref: Cf. A001221 (row lengths), A027748, A243103, A010846 (number of 1 <= m <= n | n^e), A162306 (list of 1 <= m <= n | n^e), A124010 (multiplicities of primes in n).
results.author: _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 17 2017
